@CalvinKirs Can I try to make this improvement? First time to claim issue here, getting bit of nervous, hah :)
My idea is as follows:
In `MasterTaskExecThread.java` just get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager`.
In case of worker failure and doing worker tolerance, `ZKMasterClient.java` # `failoverWorker()` method set task status to `ExecutionStatus.NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE`, and then send `CommandType.TASK_EXECUTE_RESPONSE` command containing the newest task status to master . After master process the command , `MasterTaskExecThread.java` can handle task state rightly. 
Maybe my thought is naive, looking forward to your correction.

@blackberrier Hi, I get you point. 
In your plan, there might be one thing need to consider, when a master do worker tolerance, if it cannot connect to the master that is executing this worker, how to handle this situation. 
There may two possible reason for this case:
1. They may be deployed in different network centers, in the current architecture we don't require the masters to be able to communicate with each other.
2. The Master1 is crashed too.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22415594/120090088-67dd1600-c132-11eb-9f40-b195e3b1d17f.png)

If you want to modify the worker tolerance, it may be complicated.
I think in this case, you can schedule a time rotation in the cache to query `ExecutionStatus.NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE ` tasks from database and replace the cache.
What do you think?

@caoping6 Hi, there are nothing changed?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22415594/120090783-aaedb800-c137-11eb-8fed-28c6dda96bb5.png)

@ruanwenjun 
Hi, the diagram is great, and I get the point.
It seems that we have to compromise on period of getting the right task status if we want to reduce the access to database.
Then, maybe the possible way is just as you said, In `MasterTaskExecThread.java` get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager` 9 times and then query database using `processService.findTaskInstanceById(taskInstance.getId())` 1 time. That is query database once every about 10 second?
Is this method ok?

@s348268281 
it seems that we can't see file on server unless you have mounted the path where the file is in. See volume and mountVolume for detail.
For the permission problem, you should make sure the problem source is inside docker or server. In my opinion, maybe the problem comes from docker directory permission.
Maybe you can specify absolute file name instead relative one ,and docker directory diffs from server one when mounting volumes.

> @ruanwenjun
> Hi, the diagram is great, and I get the point.
> It seems that we have to compromise on period of getting the right task status if we want to reduce the access to database.
> Then, maybe the possible way is just as you said, In `MasterTaskExecThread.java` get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager` 9 times and then query database using `processService.findTaskInstanceById(taskInstance.getId())` 1 time. That is query database once every about 10 second?
> Is this method ok?

I think in `MasterTaskExecThread ` you can get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager ` directly, and in `taskInstanceCacheManager ` schedule a timing thread to query `NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE ` task from the database and update the cache, this might be better, the `taskInstanceCacheManager` can be used by many components.

The interval of querying `NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE` task from database can be longer, for example, 10 seconds or longer?

> > @ruanwenjun
> > Hi, the diagram is great, and I get the point.
> > It seems that we have to compromise on period of getting the right task status if we want to reduce the access to database.
> > Then, maybe the possible way is just as you said, In `MasterTaskExecThread.java` get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager` 9 times and then query database using `processService.findTaskInstanceById(taskInstance.getId())` 1 time. That is query database once every about 10 second?
> > Is this method ok?
> 
> I think in `MasterTaskExecThread ` you can get status from `taskInstanceCacheManager ` directly, and in `taskInstanceCacheManager ` schedule a timing thread to query `NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE ` task from the database and update the cache, this might be better, the `taskInstanceCacheManager` can be used by many components.
> 
> The interval of querying `NEED_FAULT_TOLERANCE` task from database can be longer, for example, 10 seconds or longer?

ok, I'd like to accomplish this improvement in this way.

> the DAG is created one by one, so it's better to online one by one.

Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØÊâπÈáèÂØºÂÖ•‰ªªÂä°ÔºåÈÇ£‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏äÁ∫øÂ∞ÜÊòØÁÅæÈöæ / If it is a batch import task, it will be a disaster to go online one by one

@blackberrier Looking forward to your pr. 
And one additional thing you may need to be considered here is that there are no indexes of `state`  in the `t_ds_task_instance` table. If you want to filter by state it may scan the whole table, which can be very slow, and I think you can just query the task existing in cache by id üòÑ

@syb853553110 Welcome to contribute code

This does happen, if the two master crash at the same time(If there is only one master, it's easier to reproduce).
Because currently we have multiple listeners that will listen the node changes.
https://github.com/apache/dolphinscheduler/blob/cc9e5d5d34fcf2279b267cca7df37a9e80eeba07/dolphinscheduler-server/src/main/java/org/apache/dolphinscheduler/server/master/zk/ZKMasterClient.java#L217-L228
If this listener exeucte first, it will remove the node, and will cause Master stop, and execute QuartzExecutors.shutdown method to close the datasource.

The main reason is that the listener has no order.

Here is a related issue #5491 and related pr #5497
